''[[Amos 'n' Andy#Television|The Amos 'n' Andy Show]]'' | birth_name = Harry Roscoe Moore | birth_date = {{birth date|1887|12|9}} | birth_place = [[Rock Island, Illinois|Rock Island]], Illinois, US | death_date = {{death date and age|1958|12|13|1887|12|12}} | death_place = Los Angeles, California, US | othername = | yearsactive = 1898–1958 | occupation = Actor | spouse =Hester Moore (ca. 1909-marriage dissolved 1915)
Gertrude Moore (1915-1934) [her death]
Benzonia Davis Moore
(1941-1956) [her death]
Vivian Cravens Moore
(1957-1958) [his death] | website = | notable role = George "Kingfish" Stevens on ''The Amos 'n' Andy Show'' (CBS-TV) }} '''Tim Moore''' (December 9, 1887 – December 13, 1958) was an American vaudevillian and comic actor of the first half of the 20th century. He gained his greatest recognition in the starring role of George "Kingfish" Stevens in the [[CBS]] TV's ''[[Amos 'n' Andy#Television|The Amos 'n' Andy Show]]''. He proudly stated, "I've made it a point never to tell a joke on stage that I couldn't tell in front of my mother."{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Oqw7AAAAIBAJ&sjid=6SkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3178,18595996&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Played Best Theatres Of The World|author=Johnson, Lillian|date=February 22, 1941|publisher=The Afro-American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} ==Biography== ===Early years=== Moore was born '''Harry Roscoe Moore''' in [[Rock Island, Illinois]], one of 13 children of Harry and Cynthia Moore.{{cite web|url=http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-4gDh277r_J4/TZzPaV_bmvI/AAAAAAAABD0/ozhyDH9GXM0/s1600/Picture+1345.jpg|title=Photo of Tim Moore with his parents and six of his seven brothers|date=August 13, 1995|publisher=Rock Island Argus|accessdate=June 3, 2011}} His father was a night watchman at a brewery. Tim Moore dropped out of grammar school to work at odd jobs in town and even danced for pennies in the streets with his friend, Romeo Washburn.{{cite web|url=http://www.blackpast.org/?q=aah/moore-tim-1888-1958|title=Tim Moore|publisher=BlackPast.org|accessdate=October 21, 2010}} In 1898, Moore and Washburn went into [[vaudeville]] in an act called "Cora Miskel and Her Gold Dust Twins." It was booked by agents and travelled through the United States and even Great Britain.{{cite web|url=http://black-face.com/Tim-Moore.htm|title=Tim Moore|publisher=Black-face.com|accessdate=September 28, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://yodaslair.com/dumboozle/tmoore/golddust.html|title=Tim Moore: The Gold Dust Twins|publisher=Yoda'sLair.com|accessdate=November 10, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fultonhistory.com/Process%20small/Newspapers/New%20York%20NY%20Clipper%201853%20-%201924/New%20York%20NY%20Clipper%201904-1905.pdf/New%20York%20NY%20Clipper%201904-1905%20-%200133.pdf|title=New York City-(Brooklyn)-Fulton Street Theater|date=April 2, 1904|publisher=The New York Clipper|accessdate=June 12, 2011}} ([[PDF]]) By 1904, the act had performed with the [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus|Barnum & Bailey Circus]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fultonhistory.com/Process%20Small/Newspapers/New%20York%20NY%20Clipper%201853%20-%201924/New%20York%20NY%20Clipper%201904-1905.pdf/New%20York%20NY%20Clipper%201904-1905%20-%200817.pdf#xml=http://www.fultonhistory.com/dtSearch/dtisapi6.dll?cmd=getpdfhits&u=fffffffff50ceeeb&DocId=11210787&Index=Z%3a%2fFulton%20Historical&HitCount=2&hits=13bf+13c0+&SearchForm=C%3a%5cinetpub%5cwwwroot%5cFulton%5fNew%5fform%2ehtml&.pdf|title=Vaudeville and Minstrel|date=October 22, 1904|publisher=The New York Clipper|accessdate=June 12, 2011}} ([[PDF]]) As Moore and Washburn grew older, the act became less effective and Miss Miskel sent them back to their parents in Rock Island. Shortly after this, Moore joined the medicine show of "Doctor Mick" (Charles S. Mick), who sold a patented [[quackery|quack]] remedy called ''Pru-ri-ta''. Doctor Mick travelled through the Midwestern states, with songs and dances provided by Moore and four [[Kickapoo people|Kickapoo]] Indians. The young man also worked in a carnival [[sideshow]] and gave guided tours as a "native" tour guide in Hawaii. ===Boxing and vaudeville years=== [[File:Tim Moore early photo.jpg|left|thumb|180px|Early photo of Tim Moore.]] Moore left Doctor Mick, first to become a [[stableboy]] and later a jockey. He also tried his hand as a boxer.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=63QhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8ogFAAAAIBAJ&pg=662,1699770&dq=charles+correll&hl=en|title=TV Amos 'n' Andy Kingfish is Dead|date=December 15, 1958|publisher=Tri City Herald|accessdate=October 11, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LyomAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5_0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=3837,5461865&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Harlem Rambles-Down Memory Lane With Tim Moore|author=Tyler, George|date=February 21, 1931|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} He returned to performing about 1906, with a troupe of [[minstrel]]s called "[[The Rabbit's Foot Company]]."{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rasnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=nAQGAAAAIBAJ&pg=6122,2035468&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=The Rabbit Foot Company|date=August 1, 1908|publisher=The Freeman|accessdate=November 9, 2010}} By 1908, he was back in vaudeville and had met and married his first wife, Hester. They performed as a team, "The Moores - Tim & Hester", appearing in the United States and abroad.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fRsnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bQMGAAAAIBAJ&pg=6343,6317750&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Tim and Hester Moore Presenting 'In Dark Town Suffragette'|date=November 8, 1913|publisher=The Freeman|accessdate=October 21, 2010}} In 1910, the couple was part of an act called the Four Moores.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fxInAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YgMGAAAAIBAJ&pg=3729,2638274&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=The Pekin, Richmond, VA.|date=October 1, 1910|publisher=The Freeman|accessdate=October 21, 2010}} They next performed together in "Georgia Sunflowers," a minstrel show that played the southern vaudeville circuit.{{cite book|title=The African American Theatre Directory, 1816-1960: A Comprehensive Guide to Early Black Theatre Organizations, Companies, Theatres, and Performing Groups|editor-last=Peterson|editor-first=Bernard L.|year=1997|publisher=Greenwood Press|pages=336|isbn=0-313-29537-9|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g4lAenLSxGQC&pg=PA90&lpg=PA90&dq=dixie+songbirds+randolph&source=bl&ots=GysXH-6ugA&sig=yNSDArUGxa760eliaKrpjlvL0qA&hl=en&ei=B9nATMHOCYmaOsfM7PEL&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&sqi=2&ved=0CCsQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore&f=false|accessdate=October 21, 2010}} The Moores drew glowing reviews, Hester for her singing and Tim for his comedy.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=URsnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bQMGAAAAIBAJ&pg=5402,3228457&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Tim and Hester Moore|date=December 21, 1912|publisher=The Freeman|accessdate=November 23, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JRsnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bQMGAAAAIBAJ&pg=4471,229882&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Tim Moore and Wife as a Heavy Box Office Attraction at the Monogram|date=January 27, 1912|publisher=The Freeman|accessdate=November 23, 2010}} By 1914, both Moores were co-stars of an act that was billed as ''Tim Moore and Tom Delaney & Co.''. Tim played the tuba and Hester played drums as part of a band. Moore's own stock company was responsible for all aspects of it.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XqknAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lAQGAAAAIBAJ&pg=5397,1300611&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Dayton, Ohio|date=May 9, 1914|publisher=The Freeman|accessdate=November 9, 2010}} The couple toured China, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, the Fiji Islands and Hawaii with a vaudeville troupe. The marriage ended in divorce in 1915, and in September, Moore married a vaudeville actress named Gertrude Brown.{{cite web|url=http://www.anb.org/articles/18/18-03795.html|title=Tim Moore|publisher=American National Biography|author=Wepman, Dennis|accessdate=March 15, 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KpI8AAAAIBAJ&sjid=7SkMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2759,6335293&dq=ernestine+wade&hl=en|title=50th Year for Lincoln Theater|date=September 12, 1959|publisher=Baltimore Afro American|accessdate=March 17, 2011}} After more than a year on the road in vaudeville in the United States, the Hawaiian Islands, Australia and New Zealand, he returned to boxing as "Young Klondike", training in [[New Zealand]]. He fought there and in Australia, England, and [[Scotland]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5hEnAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NwMGAAAAIBAJ&pg=2478,769590&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Two Comedians|date=June 23, 1934|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} Before this, Moore fought as "Kid Klondike" in the US, with [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]] and [[Sam Langford]] as some of his opponents.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uV8bAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-k0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=1713,2987825&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Joe Williams says|author=Williams, Joe|date=February 8, 1951|publisher=The Pittsburgh Press|accessdate=April 20, 2011}} Moore also made his way into films by 1915, playing the part of an egotistical musician in ''His Inspiration''.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vZ8LAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PlQDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2237,6475957&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title='His Inspiration'|date=January 18, 1915|publisher=The Evening Independent|accessdate=October 21, 2010}} While Tim and Gertie were entertaining in New Zealand, a story in ''The Evening Post'' from May 28, 1917, went on to say, "Another "star" item will be that of Tim and Gertie Moore, who have earned a big reputation in America, and were booked for Fuller's direct from the well-known Orpheum circuit."{{cite news|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=EP19170528.2.25.3|title=His Majesty's Theatre|date=May 28, 1917|publisher=The Evening Post|accessdate=November 10, 2010}} Moore became well known for his one-man presentation of ''[[Tom Shows|Uncle Tom's Cabin]]'', where he would play the role of both Simon Legree and Uncle Tom, applying white chalk to half his face, and burnt cork to the other.{{cite web|url=http://yodaslair.com/dumboozle/tmoore/tmoordex.html|title=Tim Moore|publisher=Yoda'sLair.com|accessdate=November 10, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aaregistry.org/historic_events/view/more-kingfish-actor-tim-moore|title=More than the Kingfish, Actor Tim Moore|publisher=African American Registry|accessdate=November 10, 2010}}{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of the Harlem Renaissance: Volume 2|editor-last=Wintz|editor-first=Cary D.|editor2-last=Finkelman|editor2-first=Paul|pages=1392|publisher=Routledge|year=2004|isbn=1-57958-389-X|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NgIYlUbaoAoC&pg=PA810&lpg=PA810&dq=uncle+tom's+cabin+tim+moore&source=bl&ots=ICsC3R9r3b&sig=yEvktvPSk3SsO-lG9iVHe7GTO8A&hl=en&ei=vXzyTJPAOszAnAelocyJCg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&sqi=2&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=uncle%20tom's%20cabin%20tim%20moore&f=false|accessdate=November 28, 2010}} Moore literally took his one man act into the street of San Jose, California, for the sale of [[War savings stamps|War Stamps]] in 1918.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3no1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=luMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1534,1890831&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=The Jose|date=August 13, 1918|publisher=The Freeman|accessdate=November 23, 2010}} Having made $141,000 with his fists, in 1921 Moore and his wife returned to performing full-time in vaudeville.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=iB8mAAAAIBAJ&sjid=z_0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=4791,425578&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Says 'Dead' Chinese Actors Rise to Bow to Audiences|author=McCollum, Obie|date=May 21, 1927|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 21, 2010}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Gx3HzvAuMYC&pg=PA85&dq=amos+n+andy&hl=en&ei=ydxxTYj0H8TpgQeSvJm7AQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDcQ6AEwADj6AQ#v=onepage&q=amos%20n%20andy&f=false|title=Why the Stars Go Broke|publisher=Ebony|date=July 1963|accessdate=March 8, 2011}} He formed his Chicago Follies troupe and was a favorite on the [[Theater Owners Bookers Association]] vaudeville circuit during the "[[Roaring Twenties]]"{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=SD5GAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ceUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3727,1274524&dq=tim+moore+chicago+follies&hl=en|title=Tim Moore's Chicago Follies Co.|publisher=The Afro American|date=December 21, 1923|accessdate=October 21, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sUxGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=f-UMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6286,1494719&dq=tim+moore+chicago+follies&hl=en|title=What the Stage Stars Were Doing 10 Years Ago|publisher=The Afro American|date=February 27, 1932|accessdate=October 21, 2010}} period. In 1923, Moore and his wife co-starred with [[Sandy Burns]], Fannetta Burns, [[Walter Long (actor)|Walter Long]], and Bobby Smart in a silent film comedy, ''His Great Chance,'' directed by Ben Strasser (North State Film Corp.). The following year, the Moores toured vaudeville together in "Aces and Queens". Subsequently, he went on tour as one of the stars of producer Edward E. Daley's "black and white musical comedy sensation", ''Rarin' to Go'', for three seasons on the Columbia Burlesque Wheel (1925, 1926 and 1927 editions). {{clear|left}} ===Broadway comedian=== In June 1925, Tim Moore made his Broadway debut as the star of ''Lucky Sambo'' (based on "Aces and Queens'). However, the show closed after only a few performances. He was a success in burlesque in the mid 1920s with the hit show ''Rarin' to Go'', followed by a return to vaudeville in 1927 with ''The Southland Revue''.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=95BXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=f0QNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2871,1601721&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Rarin' To Go|publisher=The Toledo News-Bee|date=6 September 1926|accessdate=21 October 2010}} Moore wrote all of his own material and also did some writing for other performers; a Moore skit called, ''Not a Fit Night for Man nor Beast'', was bought by [[W.C. Fields]]. He also did some writing for the radio show of the [[Two Black Crows]] comedy team. Moore was brought to New York to sign a writing contract but before this was done, Charles Mack of the team was killed in an auto accident, thus ending the act. Moore wrote sketches which became part of Lew Leslie's "Blackbirds" revues as well.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7349AAAAIBAJ&sjid=XisMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2557,14267381&dq=amanda+randolph&hl=en|title=This Week in the Theatres|date=July 14, 1928|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=March 17, 2011}} In 1928, Moore took time off from his vaudeville bookings to try his luck once more on the Great White Way – [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]. This time he met with enormous success as the star comedian of Lew Leslie's hit musical comedy revue, the ''[[Blackbirds of 1928]]''.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5H49AAAAIBAJ&sjid=XisMAAAAIBAJ&pg=848,12924983&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Tim Moore To Be 'Blackbird'|date=April 21, 1928|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=November 23, 2010}} Moore's co-stars were singers [[Adelaide Hall]] and [[Aida Ward]] and renowned tap dancer [[Bill "Bojangles" Robinson]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6H49AAAAIBAJ&sjid=XisMAAAAIBAJ&pg=796,13462050&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Sees Aida Ward As Future 'Flo' Mills|date=May 26, 1928|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 21, 2010}} The hit musical scored high in Paris and London as well as on the road throughout the states. In 1931, Moore and his then vaudeville straight man, Andrew Tribble,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LiomAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5_0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=5142,5082767&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Harlem Rambles|author=Tyler, George|date=February 14, 1931|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=February 16, 2010}} performed one of their funniest routines in [[Oscar Micheaux]]'s first talking picture, ''[[Darktown Revue|The Darktown Revue]]''. After a disagreement with [[Lew Leslie]], Moore starred in two unsuccessful Broadway revues for other producers, ''Fast and Furious'' (1931),{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WIk9AAAAIBAJ&sjid=aisMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2650,638208&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=3 Leading Comedians Neither Sing Nor Dance; But Are Hits|date=October 10, 1931|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} and ''The Blackberries of 1932''.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CegmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BgMGAAAAIBAJ&pg=3864,3904705&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=1932: In Which Father Time Puts on The Worst Act Of His Career|date=December 24, 1932|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} In the former, Moore wrote some of the skits along with his friend and co-star [[Zora Neale Hurston]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Yn89AAAAIBAJ&sjid=XisMAAAAIBAJ&pg=799,29128795&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Many New Plays Slated To Run On Broadway|date=August 8, 1931|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} Moore and fellow comedian "Morton" (i.e., [[Mantan Moreland]]) left the show in April 1932, refusing to perform what were termed "dirty lines".{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=u0xGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=f-UMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4784,3869253&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Wouldn't Be Dirty, Comedians Quit Show|date=May 7, 1932|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 21, 2010}} Needing each other, he and Leslie patched up their differences and Moore resumed his position as star comedian in the ''Blackbirds'' revues of 1934, 1935, 1936, 1937, and 1939. Politics played a role in the demise of the 1936 edition of the ''Blackbirds'', causing the London run to be shut down. At the time the troupe was booked in the United Kingdom, [[King Edward VIII]] had just abdicated the British throne for love of American [[Wallis Simpson]]. There was a wave of anti-Americanism, with women picketing performances of the ''Blackbirds'', carrying signs disparaging American women.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_fwmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=GwMGAAAAIBAJ&pg=5787,6094214&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Who Killed Mr. Leslie's Blackbirds?|author=Matthews, Ralph|date=February 13, 1937|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} In this last of the ''Blackbirds'' (1939), the principal singing star was [[Lena Horne]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4BI1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=xaULAAAAIBAJ&pg=2546,3195996&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=New Romantic Opera|date=March 19, 1937|publisher=The Glasgow Herald|accessdate=October 16, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GxAmAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ov0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=6145,5785674&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title='Blackbirds' To Get Another Try|date=February 11, 1939|publisher=Washington Afro-American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} Moore's last Broadway show was ''Harlem Cavalcade'' (1942), produced by [[Ed Sullivan]] and [[Noble Sissle]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HZ4lAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4_QFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2260,2039559&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Cavalcade Scores On Broadway|author=Wilson, Cleon|date=May 5, 1942|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} During the late 1930s and early 1940s, Moore was one of the top comedians headlining at the [[Apollo Theater]] in [[Harlem]]. He also performed on radio as a dramatic actor.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vKA9AAAAIBAJ&sjid=visMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2010,6187583&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Eva Jessye In Radio Play|date=April 8, 1933|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vaA9AAAAIBAJ&sjid=visMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2642,6320755&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=On The Air-Eva Jessye, Radio Actress|date=April 22, 1933|author=Bowen, Charles I.|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=November 23, 2010}} In 1946, he starred as Bumpsie in the musical comedy film, ''[[Boy! What a Girl!]]''.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xRomAAAAIBAJ&sjid=of0FAAAAIBAJ&pg=5147,4987800&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Marva Forced Out of New Film By Infected Throat|date=September 28, 1946|publisher=The Afro American|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} He made some appearances on [[Ed Sullivan]]'s television show, ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show|Toast of the Town]]'', and at the Apollo Theater; Moore then retired from show business.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=128zAAAAIBAJ&sjid=P9oFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4147,289289&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Amos 'n' Andy Look For Exit As They Plan New TV Show|date=June 17, 1951|publisher=Reading Eagle|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} His wife Gertrude having died in 1934, Moore settled down with his third wife, Benzonia Davis Moore (1889–1956), in his home town of Rock Island, working the night shift at the Servus Rubber company, where boots and shoes were made. The couple was married in 1941 and initially made their home in Baltimore. ===Television stardom=== In 1950, Moore was recommended by his old vaudeville friend, [[Flournoy Miller]], for the role of George "Kingfish" Stevens, a role which was voiced on radio by white actor [[Freeman Gosden]]. He was called out of retirement by the [[Columbia Broadcasting System]] to star in a new television adaptation of ''[[Amos 'n' Andy]]''.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jncxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Yn0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3569,1199892&dq=freeman+gosden&hl=en|title=Amos And Andy Name Subs For Television Roles|date=June 18, 1951|publisher=St. Petersburg Times|accessdate=October 11, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ZCNWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=u-IDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6812,6572779&dq=spencer+williams&hl=en|title=Radio's Veteran Comics Smash Hit on Television|date=April 14, 1954|publisher=Eugene Register-Guard|accessdate=March 12, 2011}} As the radio series had developed in prior years, the scheming but henpecked Kingfish had become the central focus of most of the plots. In the television version, Moore played the character more broadly, with louder and more forceful delivery and a distinctive Georgia drawl, exaggerated for comic effect. Moore's Kingfish dominated the calmer and soft-spoken "Amos 'n' Andy" characters. Early in his career, Moore had developed a "con-man" routine he used for many years while in vaudeville; re-working some aspects of his old act produced the television character Kingfish. Moore was very popular in the show and for the first time in his career became a national celebrity as well as the first African American to win stardom on television. When leaving a train in Albuquerque to buy some Native American pottery, the proprietor recognized him immediately, saying, "You, you Kingfish." This was the first time it happened in Moore's 52 years in show business.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4ccKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hU8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3384,3553696&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=The Lyons Den|author=Lyons, Leonard|date=August 11, 1951|publisher=St. Petersburg Times|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} The show aired on prime-time TV from June 1951 to June 1953. Although quite popular, the series was eventually canceled due to complaints about ethnic stereotyping. Shortly after the television show left the air, there were plans to turn it into a vaudeville act in August 1953, with Moore, Williams, and Childress playing the same characters.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=i3ZGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fuUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2121,173955&dq=spencer+williams&hl=en|title='Amos 'n' Andy' Set for Vaude|date=August 4, 1953|publisher=Baltimore Afro-American|accessdate=April 20, 2011}} It is not known if this was ever realized. After the series was canceled, it was shown in [[Broadcast syndication|syndication]] until 1966 when increasing condemnation and pressure from the NAACP persuaded the show's owners (CBS, which still owns the copyrights) to withdraw it from further exhibition. It was resurrected in the early days of home videotape through [[public domain video dealers]] who had acquired episodes from collectors of used 16mm TV prints, although the copyright was never in the public domain. Illegally produced copies continue to be sold over the internet. The series itself would not be seen on a regular basis again until independent network Rejoice TV began re-airing episodes in 2012. Many of the episodes revolved around Moore's Kingfish character, supported by [[Ernestine Wade]] as his level-headed, emotionally strong wife Sapphire, and [[Amanda Randolph]] as his openly aggressive mother-in-law, without the participation of Amos or Andy. These Kingfish-only episodes were originally produced as a spinoff series, ''[[The Adventures of Kingfish]]'', which made its debut on CBS on January 4, 1955 but lasted only a few episodes.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SrIDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA60&dq=tim+moore+intitle:jet&hl=en&ei=7XKyTPS8AZnLngfyw9nuBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CCgQ6AEwATgU#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore%20intitle%3Ajet&f=false|title=New 'Kingfish' Series To Make TV Debut Jan. 4|date=January 6, 1955|publisher=Jet|accessdate=October 10, 2010}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uV2gZKvQwR0C&pg=PT223&dq=ernestine+wade&hl=en&ei=3fUzTf3zMMSp8Aa0vJD3CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFgQ6AEwCTgo#v=onepage&q=ernestine%20wade&f=false|title=Make 'Em Laugh: The Funny Business of America|editor-last=Kantor|editor-first=Michael|editor2-last=Maslon|editor2-first=Lawrence|year=2008|publisher=Twelve|pages=384|isbn=978-0-446-50531-4|accessdate=March 17, 2011}} When the ''Amos 'n' Andy'' half-hours went into syndication, the ''Adventures of Kingfish'' shows were added to the syndicated package under the ''Amos 'n' Andy'' series title. In 1956, Moore and his fellow cast mates [[Spencer Williams (actor)|Spencer Williams]], [[Alvin Childress]] and [[Lillian Randolph]] with her choir, tried a tour of personal appearances as "The TV Stars of ''Amos 'n' Andy''". The tour was halted by [[CBS]], who viewed this as infringing on their exclusivity.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4uK_KEF-KT8C&pg=PA66&dq=all+about+amos+'n'+andy&hl=en&ei=2FShTKjXEdP_nQfR7L2IBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=all%20about%20amos%20'n'%20andy&f=false|title=The Tragedy of Amos 'n' Andy|author=Clayton, Edward T.|date=October 1961|publisher=Ebony|accessdate=September 27, 2010}} Moore, and fellow cast members Williams, Childress and Lee, were able to perform for one night in 1957 in [[Windsor, Ontario]], since legal action had not been taken against them in Canada.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BSM_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=2k8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=3663,3973138&dq=spencer+williams&hl=en|title=The Theatre and its People|author=Gardiner, John|date=June 25, 1957|publisher=The Windsor Daily Star|accessdate=March 12, 2011}} ===Later years=== Moore married his last wife Vivian Cravens (1912–1988) eight months after Benzonia's death; they had been performing as a comedy team for some time before marrying in 1957.{{cite news|url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/13916400/tim_moore_wedding/|title=Amos 'n' Andy Show Figure To Wed Today|date=June 6, 1957|publisher=The Sun|page=3|accessdate=November 10, 2010|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tlkbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r0wEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1515,796290&dq=tim+moore&hl=en|title=Casino Features Chinese Dancer|date=December 12, 1945|publisher=The Pittsburgh Press|accessdate=October 16, 2010}} This marriage won him considerable publicity thanks to the "Roast Beef Scandal" of January 1958. Moore fired a gunshot in his home because of his "mooching in-laws" (stepson, stepdaughter, and her husband) when he found that the last of the New Year's roast beef had been eaten by them. Moore related, "These free-loaders have eaten everything in the house. My wife protects them and every time we talk about it, we get into an argument. The argument got a little loud and the next thing I knew, the big boy (his stepson Hubbard) jumped out of his chair. I ran upstairs and got out my old pistol. I didn't want to hit anybody."{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EbgDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA60&dq=tim+moore+intitle:jet&hl=en&ei=V5XaTN_ICMqdnAe17s3eAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CDkQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore%20intitle%3Ajet&f=false|title=TV Kingfish and His Sapphire in Real-Life Domestic Brawl|date=January 16, 1958|publisher=Jet|accessdate=November 10, 2010}} When the police arrived at the home, Moore, pistol still in his belt, told them, "I'm the old Kingfish, boys. I'm the one you want. I fired that shot. I didn't want to hit anyone, although I could have. Anyway, you should have seen the in-laws scatter when I fired that gun." The shot Moore fired hit the china cabinet; he was arrested and charged with assault with a deadly weapon, with police calling him the "funniest prisoner in police history." Moore was initially ordered held on $1,000 bond; the judge changed his mind and released Moore on his own recognizance.{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/thedailymirror/2008/01/paul-coates-8.html|title=The Daily Mirror|date=January 29, 2008|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=December 8, 2010}} Tim and his wife reconciled, with Vivian's pleading for the charges to be dropped.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NbcDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA16&dq=tim+moore&hl=en&ei=MJTaTJKqLIqfnAet3vzvBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore&f=false|title=Kingfish Dismissal Plea Denied, 2 Make Up|date=January 30, 1958|publisher=Jet|accessdate=November 10, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sitcomsonline.com/photopost/showphoto.php/photo/65703/size/big/cat/792|title=Kingfish Arrested On Assault Charge|date=January 1958|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=November 10, 2010}} Moore entered a not guilty plea before the case went to trial on March 24.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FLcDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA60&dq=tim+moore+intitle:jet&hl=en&ei=V5XaTN_ICMqdnAe17s3eAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore%20intitle%3Ajet&f=false|title=Kingfish Pleads Not Guilty In Gun Fracas|date=February 27, 1958|publisher=Jet|accessdate=November 10, 2010}} He received a $100 fine and a year's probation as his sentence.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cbcDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA62&dq=tim+moore+intitle:jet&hl=en&ei=QJbaTO2qCsWOnwe40Z36Ag&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CEgQ6AEwCTgK#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore%20intitle%3Ajet&f=false|title=Kingfish Fined $100 For Roast Beef Fracas|date=April 10, 1958|publisher=Jet|accessdate=November 10, 2010}} When the story broke, local television personality and columnist [[Paul Coates]] invited Tim Moore to appear on his [[KTTV]] television show; Moore explained the situation in two guest appearances. Coates was promptly taken to task for Moore's appearances on his show by Stanley Robertson, a journalist for the African-American newspaper, the ''[[Los Angeles Sentinel]]'', calling Moore "disgraceful" and labeling the two shows with Moore as "television's darkest hour." Coates replied to his critic in his January 29, 1958 ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' column, calling Moore "a pretty wonderful, sincere man" and saying he strongly resented Robertson's attack on him. Because of the "Roast Beef Scandal," Moore was once more in demand and even received a testimonial tribute dinner from the [[Friars Club of Beverly Hills]], and appearing on ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' with [[Jack Paar]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FLgDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA30&dq=tim+moore+intitle:jet&hl=en&ei=7XKyTPS8AZnLngfyw9nuBQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCQQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore%20intitle%3Ajet&f=false|title=Words Of The Week|date=January 23, 1958|publisher=Jet|accessdate=October 10, 2010}} The publicity also won him an extended performance engagement at the legendary [[Mocambo (nightclub)|Mocambo]] nightclub. ===Death and legacy=== Moore died at age 71 on December 13, 1958 of [[pulmonary tuberculosis]] in Los Angeles, four days after his birthday. There was no money to pay for his hospital care or for his funeral, Moore having received his final $65.00 residual payment from ''Amos 'n' Andy'' in January 1958. At one time, Moore had made $700 per week.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fEEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA60&dq=tim+moore+intitle:jet&hl=en&ei=_GyyTPaUGIyJnQeOreH7BQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore%20intitle%3Ajet&f=false|title=Critically Ill, Kingfish Tells Wife Of Fears, Disappointments|date=December 18, 1958|publisher=Jet|accessdate=October 10, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=csMlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MfUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=877%2C7527195|title=Kingfish Succumbs|date=December 16, 1958|publisher=Baltimore Afro-American|accessdate=November 11, 2010}} After a large funeral at Mt. Sinai Baptist Church, he was buried at [[Angelus-Rosedale Cemetery|Rosedale Cemetery]]. At the funeral service, 10,000 fans and mourners passed his open coffin; attendees included [[Groucho Marx]], [[Frank Sinatra]], [[Dean Martin]], [[Louis Armstrong]], [[Tony Curtis]], [[Sidney Poitier]], [[Charlie Barnet]], [[Noble Sissle]], [[Erskine Hawkins]], [[Louis Prima]], [[Freeman F. Gosden]], [[Charles Correll]], [[Spencer Williams, Jr.]], [[Alvin Childress]], [[Ernestine Wade]], [[Amanda Randolph]], [[Johnny Lee (actor)|Johnny Lee]], [[Lillian Randolph]], [[Sammy Davis, Jr.]], [[Eddie "Rochester" Anderson]], [[Andy Razaf]], [[Clarence Muse]], [[Roy Glenn]], [[Mantan Moreland]], [[Pigmeat Markham]], [[Willie Bryant]], [[Earl Grant]].{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jkEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA59&dq=ernestine+wade+intitle:jet&hl=en&ei=TGuyTLHeO4iNnQfE26GQBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=ernestine%20wade%20intitle%3Ajet&f=false|title=10,000 Mourners See TV's Kingfish Buried In style|date=January 8, 1959|publisher=Jet|accessdate=October 10, 2010}}[https://www.newspapers.com/image/40015912/?terms=%22Tim%2BMoore%22%2Bfuneral "Top Names at Kingfish's Funeral]" page 23, "The Pittsburgh Courier," January 3, 1959{{cite book|title=Harry Moore, TV's Kingfish|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eUEDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA56&dq=tim+moore+intitle:jet&hl=en&ei=_GyyTPaUGIyJnQeOreH7BQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore%20intitle%3Ajet&f=false|date=December 25, 1958|publisher=Jet|accessdate=October 10, 2010}} [[Sammy Davis, Jr.]] later related that [[Frank Sinatra]] organized the effort to pay Tim Moore's funeral expenses.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=10EDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA56&dq=tim+moore+intitle:jet&hl=en&ei=O3CyTMG3A9Ofngfntu2iBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CEQQ6AEwCDgK#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore%20intitle%3Ajet&f=false|title=Sinatra A Complex, Honest Guy, Says Sammy|date=March 12, 1959|publisher=Jet|accessdate=October 10, 2010}} Moore's grave remained unmarked from the time of his burial until 1983; fellow comedians [[Redd Foxx]] and [[George Kirby]] raised funds for a headstone.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=prYDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA36&dq=tim+moore&hl=en&ei=xoraTMOdC4ejnAfH2cjeAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CC0Q6AEwATgy#v=onepage&q=tim%20moore&f=false|title=Kingfish Discovery|date=August 15, 1983|publisher=Jet|accessdate=November 10, 2010}} There is now one marking the graves of Moore and his wife, Vivian, who died in 1988.{{cite web|url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=pv&GRid=6637577&PIpi=1232018|title=Tim and Vivian Moore Headstone|publisher=Find A Grave|accessdate=November 10, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/13915925/vivian_moore/ |title=Widow of actor 'Kingfish' dies|date=January 14, 1988|publisher=Reno Gazette-Journal|accessdate=September 22, 2017|page=50|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} Paying tribute to one of its favorite sons, the Rock Island Public Library held "Tim Moore Day" July 16, 2008. Moore's relatives in the area participated by sharing their memories of his life and work.{{cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/13916211/tim_moore_day/|title=Tim Moore Day|date=June 16, 2008|page=16|publisher=Quad City Times|accessdate=September 22, 2017|via = [[Newspapers.com]]}} {{Open access}} In spite of his achievement as the first major African American television star, Moore is still not honored with a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]. ==References== ;Notes {{Reflist|30em}} ;Works cited *[[Donald Bogle|Bogle, Donald]].
